subject: Re: How to log JUnits Tests
msgSnippet: Thank you for your answer. Am I right? JUnit generates his own reports for failed tests? How can I catch them? Or what do you mean with reports for aggregate
messageBody:
Thank you for your answer.
Am I right? JUnit generates his own reports for failed tests? How can
I catch them? Or what do you mean with reports for aggregate
information? Are that reports different from the logging I generate
with eg log4j?

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@... wrote:
>
> That sounds like two different things:
>
> The logging, whether through log4j (which I also like) or something
else, will provide debugging information to you.
>
> The reports are useful for aggregate information (like how many
failures and errors for X number of tests for the whole product
suite, or whatever scope you run) and information about tests passed
and failed (errors and failures).
>
> For the tests that failed, you might use the information from the
report (which will give you information around the issue - stack
trace or failure information) or information from the log files
(information for the entire run - you might be able to see the
progression of state that led to the failure/error) to troubleshoot
and fix.
>
> I generally take the reports, or the result of an individual run,
as my starting point, and then only look at the logging for the ones
that failed in some way. If I have written my asserts well, I
usually don't even need to look at the logging, because I will know
exactly what went wrong.
>
> Hope this helps and good luck on the migration.
>
>
> Dianne
>
> -------------- Original message --------------
> From: "isowitz" <isowitz@...>
> I have to rewrite existing tests in JUnit tests. The old tests logs
> with a java.util.logging.Logger, e.g. starttime, start sendind
data,
> start recieving data, the recieved data etc. - in a word they logs
> all that can be logged.
> Should I use the java.util.logging.Logger for JUnit too or is that
> the bad way?
>
> You spoke about reports of my result. What other kind of reports
> exists?
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@ wrote:
> >
> > What do you mean by logging,...do you mean reports of your
results -
> then Google JUnitReport.
> >
> > -------------- Original message --------------
> > From: "isowitz" <isowitz@>
> > I have a problem with logging JUnit tests. In a package I have a
> > AllTests class that calls several tests. The result of that tests
> > should be logged.
> > I'm not familiar with JUnit or logging so I try to find examples
in
> the
> > web. Unfortunately i found no examples or hints for me.
> >
> > How do you log your JUnit results?
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
> >
>
>
>
